article.description:
Kerry Kittles made five 3-pointers, Jason Kidd made four and the New Jersey Nets shot 14-for-24 from beyond the arc, defeating New York 114-96 Sunday night and sending the Knicks to their fourth
straight loss.
article.headline: Nets pull ahead of idle Celtics in Atlantic

images.name: Kidd_Jason 121601 inline
images.caption: Jason Kidd, not known for his shooting, hit four 3-pointers.

article.linkText: Nets fire from 3-point range to rip Knicks
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- The Don Chaney era is not unfolding well for the New York Knicks. Kerry Kittles made five 3-pointers, Jason Kidd made four and the New Jersey Nets shot 14-for-24 from beyond the arc, defeating the defensively inept New York Knicks 114-96 Sunday night and sending them to their fourth straight loss. The Knicks had only one four-game losing streak in Jeff Van Gundy's six-plus seasons as coach, yet Chaney already has his first after coaching the team for just five games. "If it was me, I'd point the finger at what we do as players. We're the guys on the floor," Latrell Sprewell said. "Game plans are great, but if you don't go out there and execute them, then they're nothing." Kittles finished with 27 points, Kidd had 18 points and 14 assists and Kenyon Martin also scored 21 for the Nets, who regained sole possession of first place in the Atlantic Division by a half-game over the idle Boston Celtics. The Nets have beaten the Knicks four consecutive times, the first time that has happened in almost 15 years. New Jersey, which set a team record with its 14 3s, improved its record to 15-7. Last season, the Nets didn't win their 15th game until Feb. 21. "The team is very optimistic and having fun. There's no other way to put it," Kidd said. "We've got a great group of apples in the basket, everyone is competing and pushing one another, and when you win it brings out the best in everybody." Allan Houston scored 23 for the Knicks, who failed to defend the 3-point line throughout the game and allowed a season-high point total. The previous high against New York was 109 points -- also by New Jersey in a 26-point loss on Nov. 16. "When you double-team the post, you're going to get open shots like that," Martin said. Keith Van Horn made three 3-pointers and scored 17 points, and reserve Lucious Harris had a pair of 3s and finished with 12 points. The Nets created open shots by getting the ball inside to Martin. Every time they did it, the Knicks sent a second defender to help Sprewell or Othella Harrington. "I've never seen them double as much as they did," Van Horn said. Kittles hit back-to-back 3-pointers late in the fourth, the second one a fling off one foot as the shot clock was about to expire that gave the Nets a 106-92 lead. New Jersey outscored New York 32-18 in the fourth quarter. After an even first half, the Nets started to pull away when Kidd came up with consecutive steals -- one leading to a layup by Kittles, the next leading to a dunk by Kittles -- for a 63-57 lead. Martin beat everyone downcourt in transition for a layup that gave the Nets their first 10-point lead, 74-64, and Kittles hit a 3 for an 80-69 lead. The Nets shot 6-for-7 from 3-point range and 12-for-16 overall in the third quarter. Martin scored nine straight points for New Jersey early in the fourth, and the Nets stayed ahead by going 11-for-13 from the line over a stretch of 6 1/2 minutes in which they did not make a field goal. The Knicks' fourth consecutive loss came on the ninth day of Chaney's stint as head coach following the unexpected resignation of Van Gundy. "It's still early, it's still new. We're still trying to understand his vision," Thomas said. "A new coach comes in and he has his own vision of what he sees the team doing. It takes time, just like when you bring new players in. "Before Jeff left we were starting to get in a rhythm and each guy understood his role on the court, now with Jeff gone we have to redefine our roles," Thomas said.

Game notes
Knicks forward Clarence Weatherspoon saw the team doctor Sunday and was cleared to wear an air cast instead of a walking boot on his injured right foot. Weatherspoon, who has a torn tendon, will be re-evaluated at midweek. ... A fan brought an oversized milk carton with a picture of Van Gundy's face on it. ... New York's last four-game losing streak was April 14-19, 1999. ... The Nets improved to 7-0 when scoring 100 or more points and 14-2 when scoring 90 or more.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
